comment.author: 69679868@N03
comment._content: Private Gordon Etheridge, Royal Newfoundland Regiment, Service Number (stated as) 1585 (CWGC has 1858), was born on 2 Jun 1892 to John and Priscilla (Batson). He was killed in action on the first day of the battle of the Somme opposite Beaumount Hamel, France on 1 Jul 1916. His brother John Charles Etheridge died of wounds received in the same attack after he was discharged from the Regiment. They are both remembered on the War Memorial in the Church Yard of St. Nicholas Anglican Church at Champney's East, Newfoundland and Labrador, Canada.// canada.virtual.museum/pm.php?id=search_record_detail&...

comment.author: 66048793@N00
comment._content: I'm not sure whether this information is useful or not, but Newfoundland did not become part of Canada until 1949--it was an independent Dominion during WWI.

comment.author: 62508825@N00
comment._content: [http://www.flickr.com/photos/lindholmorrison] Good point. The outbreak of WW1 led the Government of Newfoundland to recruit a force for service with the British Army. The regiment was virtually wiped out at Beaumont Hamel on July 1, 1916, the first day of the Battle of the Somme. Since then July 1 has been marked as Memorial Day in Newfoundland and Labrador. en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Royal_Newfoundland_Regiment#cite_no... For all intents and purposes the Newfoundland Regiment had been wiped out, the unit as a whole having suffered a casualty rate of approximately 90%. en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Beaumont-Hamel_Newfoundland_Memoria...
